Watch<u>ed</u>

data.question: John's watch is made of GOLD.

option.a: Whose watch is made of gold?
option.c: Is John's watch made of silver?
option.d: Is John's necklace made of gold?

data.section: In each of the following sentences, the word that receives the emphatic stress is written in capital letters. From the options lettered A to D, choose the appropriate answer.
data.solution: When answering emphatic stress questions, the option that does not have the "stressed word" becomes the correct answer.

data.question: She WORKS at the hospital.

option.c: Does she work at the hospital?
option.d: What does she do at the hospital?

data.section: In each of the following sentences, the word that receives the emphatic stress is written in capital letters. From the options lettered A to D, choose the appropriate answer.
data.solution: When answering emphatic stress questions, the option that does not have the "stressed word" becomes the correct answer.

data.question: Aderonke STATED she had a right to her privacy.

option.a: Did Aderonke lament she had a right to her privacy?
option.b: Did Omowunmi state she had a right to her privacy?
option.c: Did Aderonke state she had a right to his privacy?
option.d: Did Aderonke state she had a right to her openness?

data.section: In each of the following sentences, the word that receives the emphatic stress is written in capital letters. From the options lettered A to D, choose the appropriate answer.
data.solution: When answering emphatic stress questions, the option that does not have the "stressed word" becomes the correct answer.

data.question:
Choose the option that has the same consonant sound as the one represented by the letter(s) underlined.

Na<u>t</u>ional
data.solution: Both have the /ʃ/ sound.

data.question: Identify the word that has the stress on the first syllable
data.solution: Only table is stressed on the first syllable.

data.question:
From the options lettered A-D, choose the option that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word.

Twice, he was <u>repulsed</u> with heavy losses
data.solution: Repulsed means to be filled with disgust. The most nearly opposite option is gratified.

data.question: I only visited Chidi. This means that

option.b: I didn't do anything asides visiting Chidi
option.c: I didn't go with anyone to visit Chidi
option.d: I visited Chidi and his friends

data.solution: The general rule is adverbs should be placed next to the thing they modify. Here, the adverb is modifying visited .

data.question: My father is <u>parsimonious</u>
data.section: From the options lettered A-D, choose the option that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word.
data.solution: Parsimonious means to be very unwilling to spend money or use resources. The nearly opposite word is generous.

data.question: Last Easter was an <u>austere</u> period.
data.section: From the options lettered A-D, choose the option that is most nearly opposite in meaning to the underlined word.
data.solution: Austere stresses absence of warmth, color, or feeling and may apply to rigorous restraint, simplicity, or self-denial. The most nearest in meaning is prosperous.

data.question: Choose the word that has a different stress pattern
data.solution: All other options are stressed on the second syllable except basic that is stressed on the first syllable.

data.question:
Choose the option that has the same consonant sound as the one represented by the letter(s) underlined.

<u>F</u>oot
data.solution: Both words have the /f/ sound. Others have the /v/ sound.

data.question: Choose the option that has a different vowel sound from the others
data.solution: All options have /ɪə/ except head that has the /e/ sound.

data.question: Choose the option that has a different vowel sound from the others
data.solution: Only been has the /ɪ/ sound. Others have the /i:/ sound.

data.question: My account with the bank is in the red. This means that my account is
data.solution: Self-explanatory.

data.question: Between you and _____, he is a liar.
data.section: Fill in the gap with the option that best completes the sentence.
data.solution: Use the pronoun "me" when the person speaking is receiving the action of the verb in some way, either directly or indirectly.

data.question: The secretary and treasurer did not do ____ job.
data.section: Fill in the gap with the option that best completes the sentence.
data.solution: When two subjects are joined together by "and" but the two subjects refer to only one person or thing, a singular verb should be used.

data.question: If James fails his examination, his teachers, his parents, his friends, or I ______ to be blame.
data.section: Fill in the gap with the option that best completes the sentence.
data.solution: When there is a list of nouns or pronouns at the level of the subject, it is the nearest noun or pronoun to the position of the verb that will determine the choice of the verb.

data.question: I have always found that it is helpful to have a few wise and trusted people to ________ you can turn for information and advice.
data.section: Fill in the gap with the option that best completes the sentence.
data.solution: Whom should be used to refer to the object of a verb or preposition.

data.question: We ought to stay away ______ the robbers come back
data.section: Fill in the gap with the option that best completes the sentence.
data.solution: When you go to a meeting, or to your workplace you are on business, similarly if you go on an overseas trip for work you are on business.

data.question: It was _____ who killed the goat.
data.section: Fill in the gap with the option that best completes the sentence.
data.solution: He is used to replace the male subject(performer of action) of the sentence: it functions as a subject pronoun.

data.question: Bankole is upset as his wife does not understand his <u>predicament</u> .
data.section: From the options lettered A-D, choose the option that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.
data.solution: Both words mean a situation in which a difficult choice has to be made between two different things you could do.

data.question: It is wise not to depend on <u>mundane</u> things.
data.section: From the options lettered A-D, choose the option that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.
data.solution: Both means things that are of this earthly world rather than a heavenly or spiritual one.

data.question: Now that the company is <u>insolvent</u> , it will shut down.
data.section: From the options lettered A-D, choose the option that is nearest in meaning to the underlined word.
data.solution: Both mean to be unable to pay what you owe because you do not have enough money.

data.question:
Choose the option that has the same consonant sound as the one represented by the letter(s) underlined.

Mo<u>th</u>er
data.solution: Both words have the /ð/ sound.

data.question: Pick out the option with a different rhyme
data.solution: Only Growl has a different rhyme

data.question:
Choose the word that has the same rhyme

Watch
data.solution: Both words have the same rhyme.

data.question:
Choose the option that has the same stress pattern as the given word.

Student
data.solution: Refuse(N) and student are both stressed on the first syllable unlike other options stressed on the second syllable.
